messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 60 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Deeply-Debiased Off-Policy Interval Estimation

Paper Abstract: Abstract Off-policy evaluation learns a target policy‚Äôs value with a historical dataset generated by a different behavior policy. In addition to a point estimate, many applications would benefit significantly from having a confidence interval (CI) that quantifies the uncertainty of the point estimate. In this paper, we propose a novel deeply-debiasing procedure to construct an efficient, robust, and flexible CI on a target policy‚Äôs value. Our method is justified by theoretical results and numerical experiments. A Python implementation of the proposed procedure is available at https://github.com/RunzheStat/D2OPE.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 60 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 60"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Learning dexterous in-hand manipulation",
        "A finite time analysis of temporal difference learning with linear function approximation",
        "Efficient and adaptive estimation for semiparametric models, volume 4",
        "Basic properties of strong mixing conditions. a survey and some open questions",
        "Random forests",
        "Openai gym",
        "Randomized incomplete uùë¢u-statistics in high dimensions",
        "Anti-concentration and honest, adaptive confidence bands",
        "Double/debiased/neyman machine learning of treatment effects",
        "Coindice: Off-policy confidence interval estimation",
        "Maximal inequalities and empirical central limit theorems",
        "On u-statistics and v. mise‚Äôstatistics for weakly dependent processes",
        "Accurate inference for adaptive linear models",
        "Statistics of robust optimization: A generalized empirical likelihood approach",
        "A theoretical analysis of deep q-learning",
        "More robust doubly robust off-policy evaluation",
        "Accountable off-policy evaluation with kernel bellman statistics",
        "Confidence intervals for policy evaluation in adaptive experiments",
        "Bootstrapping with models: Confidence intervals for off-policy evaluation",
        "A class of statistics with asymptotically normal distribution",
        "Minimax value interval for off-policy evaluation and policy optimization",
        "Doubly robust off-policy value evaluation for reinforcement learning",
        "Efficiently breaking the curse of horizon in off-policy evaluation with double reinforcement learning",
        "Double reinforcement learning for efficient off-policy evaluation in markov decision processes",
        "Empirical likelihood methods with weakly dependent processes",
        "Batch policy learning under constraints",
        "U-statistics: Theory and Practice",
        "Batch policy learning in average reward markov decision processes",
        "Breaking the curse of horizon: Infinite-horizon off-policy estimation",
        "Evaluating the impact of treating the optimal subgroup",
        "Orthogonal machine learning: Power and limitations",
        "The ohiot1dm dataset for blood glucose level prediction",
        "Human-level control through deep reinforcement learning",
        "Semiparametric efficient empirical higher order influence function estimators",
        "Marginal mean models for dynamic regimes",
        "Dualdice: Behavior-agnostic estimation of discounted stationary distribution corrections",
        "Empirical likelihood",
        "Self-normalized processes: Limit theory and Statistical Applications",
        "Eligibility traces for off-policy policy evaluation",
        "Markov decision processes: discrete stochastic dynamic programming",
        "Higher order influence functions and minimax estimation of nonlinear functionals",
        "Minimax estimation of a functional on a structured high-dimensional model",
        "Deep reinforcement learning framework for autonomous driving",
        "Testing mediation effects using logic of boolean matrices",
        "Breaking the curse of nonregularity with subagging‚Äîinference of the mean outcome under optimal treatment regimes",
        "Does the markov decision process fit the data: testing for the markov property in sequential decision making",
        "Statistical inference of the value function for reinforcement learning in infinite horizon settings",
        "Adaptive estimator selection for off-policy evaluation",
        "Reinforcement learning: An introduction",
        "Doubly robust bias reduction in infinite horizon off-policy estimation",
        "Data-efficient off-policy policy evaluation for reinforcement learning",
        "High confidence policy improvement",
        "High-confidence off-policy evaluation",
        "Semiparametric theory and missing data",
        "Minimax weight and q-function learning for off-policy evaluation",
        "Online targeted learning",
        "Asymptotic statistics, volume 3",
        "Weak convergence",
        "Inference for batched bandits",
        "Finite-sample analysis for sarsa with linear function approximation"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 60 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Deeply-Debiased Off-Policy Interval Estimation, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
